intro: Lechea leggettii var. pulchella, commonly known as the Desert Milkweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as sandy soils and rocky habitats. Its leaves are opposite and lance-shaped, often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branched. The flowers attract a variety of pollinators, including butterflies and bees, making it an important species in its ecosystem.
